Kolkata (Calcutta in the past) is one of the most energetic and spectacular city in India. West Bengal's capital Kolkata comes third in terms of population and is the social and business center point in the eastern part of India. Reflecting on a glorious history, there are various architectural monuments in this city, and the most accurate Victoria Memorial Hall is located there among them. Working out of appreciation for Queen Victoria in 1901, this building has been turned into an excellent gallery, which shows a rich gathering of original documents, canvas, and sculpture of the British time frame in India. On this occasion that if you wish to visit Victoria Memorial Hall, at this point you can choose the local flights to Kolkata or for foreigners, you can directly choose an international flights to visit Victoria memorial hall.

The splendid structure in white marble was finished with solid long pillars and enough spacious rooms. History of Victoria Memorial Hall

After the death of Queen Victoria in 1901, the Viceroy of the nation Lord Curzon thought of building an old exhibition hall to pay tribute to the ruler. This structure was designed by Sir William Emerson, the leader of the British Institute of Architects, while the development was assumed by Ms. Martin and the company. Superintendent of this building Vincent J. Esch was there. Founding of this magnificent structure, the stone was founded by King George V in the year 1906, and formally, the Victoria Memorial Hall was opened in 1921 for an open review.

The city of Kolkata was once the capital of the British Empire. An important part of the provincial appeal is that India is famous for lying in Kolkata. Maybe the most special Victoria Memorial in all. This Magnum trumps province everything in Kolkata and marks the image of a perfection in all points. The building went back in the middle of the twentieth century and was actually an artistic culmination of Sir William Emerson. At that time, its cost was Rs. 1,50,000,000 and it was done in the memory of the late Queen Victoria. The structure itself is a mosaic of attraction, each of which demonstrates the ability of the expert. There are some different statues that depict the ideas of motherhood, architecture, learning, justice, charity, and prudence. When the remembrance was created, every idol has been brought down from Italy.

Architecture of Victoria Memorial Hall

This surrender extends with more than 64 sections of the land, in which the structure itself is 338 feet 228 feet. The height of the building is about 184 feet high, in which the figure of victory is 16 feet high. Made of white marble brought from Rajasthan, this building has a similarity to the wonderful Taj Mahal in Agra.

Similarly, there is a huge statue of Victoria which is about 5 meters high and fully made of bronze. This statue itself is of 3 tons. The grandest component of this building has an attractive light effect. When the sunshine, then the building shines from all sides.

Garden and statues

The Garden of this memorial has been structured brilliantly on the land of 64 blocks. Highly placed above, Garden area has highlighted rich green gardens and delightful blooming flowers.

In the event that you enter the memorial from the north gate, you will see a bronze statue of Queen Victoria, which contains the statue of George Frampton, RA is nearby. When you enter the South Entryway, you can see the commemoration curve of King Edward VII. Part of the alternative statues found in this reminder was from Governor General of India Lord Bentinck from 1828 to 1835 and Lord Ripon, governor-general of India from 1880 to 1884.
